Author: mithro_
Content: @Tim Edwards, @Tholin had some questions / thoughts about analog stuff on GF180MCU.

Content: Not really questions as much as I just wanna mess around and find out with some analog circuits on my next GF180 tapeout.

Author: rtimothyedwards_19428
Content: Sure, analog IP is yet another need for GF180MCU.  I would take a look at what's being produced for Chipathon.  I have been running my own track so I haven't been looking at what the analog groups have been doing, but for the record, you can find the Chipathon discussions on fossi-chat.org under the "Chipathon 2025" channel, or on github at https://github.com/sscs-ose/sscs-chipathon-2025/issues.

Author: mithro_
Content: There is a bunch of interesting information in the Chipathon page @ https://github.com/sscs-ose/sscs-chipathon-2025/tree/main/resources/Integration

Author: rtimothyedwards_19428
Content: @Tim 'mithro' Ansell :  If nothing else, Chipathon 2025 is surfacing a number of issues in the GF180MCU open PDK that needed to be addressed, and they are getting fixed, which will definitely benefit you and wafer.space for the first shuttle run.

Content: Yeap! You know I'm a big believer that quality is related to the number of users.

Author: tholin
Content: The opamps I can build here are not nearly rail-to-rail and have some nasty nonlinearities on the output the more you move away from 2.5V in either direction.

Author: tholin
Content: As for why I need a sine/cosine wave generator: I am trying to generate the chroma component of a color NTSC signal. Because why do something the easy way when you can loose your sanity doing it the hard way?

Author: mrmadbrain
Content: ooh, so it's basically close to a 3.58 mhz bandpass filter? :3

Author: peterkinget
Content: If you are looking for example projects and designs, mostly in analog, take a look at https://vlsidesignlab.org. The site has several years of project websites and videos of the VLSI design lab class at Columbia University where students design a chip in the spring, it gets fabricated in summer, and they test it in fall. There is quite a bit of design information available, and there is a search and index also. Have fun!

Author: mrmadbrain
Content: Question... Is it reasonable to try to implement an Operational Transconductance Amplifier in the target process? - something in the vein of LM13700 ( https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&source=web&rct=j&opi=89978449&url=https://www.ti.com/lit/ds/symlink/lm13700.pdf&ved=2ahUKEwiOqube6ZmQAxWEj4kEHSjgB54QFnoECBkQAQ&usg=AOvVaw3GXAglJwE-LG-Gg1gfRkxv )... if yes, I imagine it might have tighter limits on currents/voltage/wattage?

Author: mithro_
Content: @Tim Edwards - Any thoughts on @madbrain's question?

Author: valgamaa
Content: You won't have anything like the supply range of the 13700, which is over 30 volts (from memory). If that isn't an issue then there is nothing to stop you making such a circuit while also including extra circuits like a voltage-controlled input for gm control. I used a similar process for a 4MHz gm-C bandpass filter many years ago with good results, and there are many MOS 'tricks' that you can use to get significantly lower distortion than the 13700 has.

Author: mrmadbrain
Content: great to know üëç  the applications I'm looking into are boutique synthesizers so the S-curve shaped distortion is often a feature rather than a bug üòâ

Author: valgamaa
Content: You won't get a tanh curve, but you will get something similar with MOS transistors. DC offsets might need some consideration and the capacitor options on-chip will be too low density to be much use. Making the circuits differential might give the headroom you will want, and with that gyrators become very simple (that's the key to most filters in CMOS) but I doubt you will want to implement standard filter responses like Butterworth etc. I half-wondered if it might be synthesiser-related when I saw mention of the 13700!

Author: mrmadbrain
Content: yeah typically for synthesizers the more common filter types are state variable (SVF) and moog-style 4 pole ladder... often deliberately non-linear so that the response doesn't blow up when you crank up the Q-factor... might have to look into having the output current mirrors have a digitally controllable multiplication factor ü§î

Author: valgamaa
Content: The SSM2044-type topology would map onto this process pretty well, I think. How much experience do you have with MOS circuit design? Most of the blocks you would want for a synthesiser are a really good vehicle to cover most of the circuit topologies that make for good CMOS design. A temperature-insensitive VCO should also be quite practical in this process too.

Author: _.social._
Content: hi there. anyone down to talk about silicon production (analog chips) in older processes? i'm talking to a fab and they're telling me the kind of design that i am talking to them about could result in a bunch of crosstalk, so i'm looking for ideas on how to mitigate that. the chip carries analog audio, so this is about capacitive coupling.

Author: mithro_
Content: I would just do a tapeout with Tiny Tapeout and see if it matches expectations

Author: _.social._
Content: tiny tapeout is great, but my ultimate goal is to go into commercial production with a fab

Author: _.social._
Content: however, i resolved the crosstalk issue. i guess it was a translation problem between russian and english.

Author: _.social._
Content: they didn't mean to say it was going to create a bunch of crosstalk, they were telling me they had a solution which has low cross talk.

Author: _.social._
Content: they just didn't know how to say it üôÇ
